awd_titl_txt: CryptoClub Afterschool and Online: Broad Implementation
awd_abstract_narration:
As a part of its overall strategy to enhance learning in informal environments, the Advancing Informal STEM Learning (AISL) program funds research and innovative resources for use in a variety of settings.   This Broad Implementation project would scale up the CryptoClub Project, an afterschool and online program designed to engage middle school youth in mathematics and cryptography.  The project builds on previous successful work and evaluation that is ready for scale up using a train-the-trainer model implemented through a partnership with the National Girls Collaborative. The project will train 160 new CryptoClub leaders who will then train 800 new leaders at 20 hub sites reaching 9600 students.  In addition, professional development modules and webinars will continue to refresh leader skills.  Other project components include an online multiplayer cryptography game, weekly challenges through social media, and digital cryptology badges for students.  

The research uses a think-aloud method with students as they actually attempt to solve the cryptology problems using mathematical thinking. Three think-aloud studies will be performed during the Project.  The research team will code transcripts of the interviews for evidence of the mathematical thinking intended to be addressed by each activity, as well as capturing unexpected kinds of thinking. Tasks  will also be rated according to the type of knowledge elicited. A written report will include statistical analyses of the think-aloud and interview responses, interpreted in light of the overall CryptoClub goals. The findings will contribute to both future research efforts and practice. The evaluation by EDC uses a quasi-experimental design, which assesses project outcomes for trainers, leaders, students, and Internet users. EDC will also investigate the fidelity to the CryptoClub model as it is scaled up. These studies have strong potential for informing numerous other projects that are at a stage where scale up is under consideration.

por.por_cntn:
The CryptoClub Project develops materials that harness the allure of secret messages to teach cryptography and mathematics. In addition, it offers training and resources for teachers and informal educators who want to introduce students to an exciting and important application of mathematics in a playful and engaging way.

The project has two components, a curriculum for middle-grade students engaged in teacher-led "CryptoClubs" and a website, cryptoclub.org, that offers a variety of digital activities to the wider Internet audience. 

1. CLUB-BASED COMPONENT

We used the following methods to scale-up the middle-grade club-based component of the project: 

Train-the-Trainer Model: We partnered with the National Girls Collaborative project (NGCP) to train two cohorts of trainers from organizations within the NGCP network, developing a total of 17 training hubsites around the country, each with a two-year commitment. These trainers in turn trained over 200 new club leaders to lead their own CryptoClubs with youth. In addition, the project continued to host leader-training workshops in Chicago and worked with individual school districts to support teachers as they implemented clubs. 

Books:  We published the CryptoClub Student Cipher Handbook and accompanying CryptoClub Leader Manual (Beissinger, J. and Saunders, B., Kendall Hunt Publishing, 2020). Working with a commercial publisher that is established in the K-12 space has enabled us to increase our reach beyond what our project could do alone.  

Online Training: We developed the CryptoClub Online Leader Training Modules to extend opportunities for teachers who could not attend face-to-face workshops. These modules include over 80 short video-tutorials and classroom videos that accompany the chapters in our CryptoClub Student Cipher Handbook. Teachers receive a Certificate of Completion after completing the 25-30 hour training. These modules are free to teachers who purchase the CryptoClub Leader Manual. They are designed to be completed asynchronously at the learner's own pace, but since their release, we have provided additional support to two cohorts of teachers via 3 weekly Zoom meetings per cohort as they worked through the modules. Completion rates increased when teachers had this opportunity to discuss the content with project staff and other teachers.  

Virtual Learning Community: To support teachers using CryptoClub in afterschool programs and in classrooms, we developed the CryptoClub Virtual Learning Community (https://cryptoclubproject.uchicago.edu), which is a website where leaders share resources and view videos of CryptoClubs in action. Over 820 educators have joined this community. 

Other Settings: To explore implementation in other learning settings, we piloted an online CryptoClub for students during COVID. We also piloted a library-based CryptoClub to explore what adaptations are needed for our materials to be used in libraries. 

The proposed Think Aloud study mentioned in the abstract was not performed, due to the death early in the project of the researcher proposed to conduct it and later to our inability to meet with students during COVID times. 

2. ONLINE COMPONENT

We developed the following digital tools and activities to increase interest and learning in the online portion of our project, crytoclub.org:

Digital Games: In a partnership with the educational software company Eduweb, we released two new 3D digital games: V.O.R.T.E.X, which provides approximately 4 hours of game play that involves encrypting and decrypting messages, and Cipher Island, in which players engage in treasure hunts with encrypted clues and create their own hunts for other players. These games are downloadable at https://cryptoclub.org/#vGames. A one-minute preview of Cipher Island can be accessed with the same URL.

Digital Badges: We developed a system of digital badges that registered users can earn for their accomplishments on our website cryptoclub.org. There are six badges that involve encrypting, decrypting, and cracking messages for each of the six ciphers on the site. Earning badges gives a comprehensive introduction to the website's cipher tools, message boards, and games, and gives users a motivating reason to practice their cryptography skills. 

Digital App: We developed the free mobile app CryptoClub Daily Ciphers: Mathematical Cryptograms, which offers messages that have been encrypted with mathematical ciphers. Users look for patterns to help them decrypt. Messages include anecdotes about the history of cryptography, fun facts about science, and inspirational quotes. The app has descriptions and examples of the six ciphers involved, along with tools such as frequency tables to help guess letters and cipher tables to help keep track of guesses and look for patterns. We expect the app will appeal to a broad audience, from ages 10 through adult. We plan to release it in the Apple Store in August, 2024. 

Please visit our project website  cryptoclubproject.uchicago.edu  to learn more about CryptoClub and cryptoclub.org to enjoy our online tools and games.
